subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Need common abbreviation list
msgSnippet: ... Yes, slanting to the right is what I have in mind. But if it doesn t look good, c est la vie. ... Oh, sure. What--you think I ve stopped tweaking my
messageBody:
On Nov 19, 2007 3:02 PM, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Ted Larson Freeman scripsit:
>
>
> > There are several things I want from a new font: regular, bold, italic,
> > bold italic; both serif and sans serif typefaces, etc.
>
> What do you have in mind for italics? Just slanting to the right will
> not, I think, work. Most other scripts have no real analogue of it,
> except Greek and Cyrillic, both of which were redesigned in modern times
> to be more like Latin.

Yes, slanting to the right is what I have in mind. But if it doesn't
look good, c'est la vie.


> > A strong desire to change the keyboard mapping was one of the original
> > motivators for me, actually.
>
> Note that you can change the font mapping in an existing font without
> changing the font glyphs.

Oh, sure. What--you think I've stopped tweaking my Dvorak-inspired
keyboard layout for the usual alphabet?

Seriously, for me, having a well-designed one-to-one correspondence
between QS and Latin letters is a prized design goal.

> > I'm a scientist, not an artist, so don't expect anything of beauty
> > any time soon.
>
> Euclid alone has looked on Beauty bare.
> Let all who prate of Beauty hold their peace,
> And lay them prone upon the earth and cease
> To ponder on themselves, the while they stare
> At nothing, intricately drawn nowhere
> In shapes of shifting lineage; let geese
> Gabble and hiss, but heroes seek release
> From dusty bondage into luminous air.
>
> O blinding hour, O holy, terrible day,
> When first the shaft into his vision shone
> Of light anatomized! Euclid alone
> Has looked on Beauty bare. Fortunate they
> Who, though once only and then but far away,
> Have heard her massive sandal set on stone.
>
> --Edna St. Vincent Millay (1923)

Ah, crap. You can quote poetry?? Well, I can quote...

"When you come to a fork in the road, take it."
"Ninety percent of this game is half mental."
Yogi Berra


Ted



> Well, I have news for our current leaders John Cowan
> and the leaders of tomorrow: the Bill of cowan@...
> Rights is not a frivolous luxury, in force http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
> only during times of peace and prosperity.
> We don't just push it to the side when the going gets tough. --Molly Ivins
>
